results.notes:
Psathyrella (Fr.) Qul., Bolbitiaceae, Agaricales .
Small light brown mushroom with white gills and narrow long white stalk
Cap: 2-4 cm wide, cone or bell-shaped up to convex minor broad convex; smooth; color light brown. Flesh is thin and white.
Gills: almost free or attached with pinching out end, moderately broad, rather close and distant, with short and very short additional gills; white or whitish.
Stalk: 6-10 cm long, 4-8mm thick, slightly enlarged toward base, hollow, fine fibrous or somewhat silky; white or whitish.
Edibility: no accurate data for this location; possibly edible, because the odor is weak and pleasant.
Habitat: rare kind; scattered small group on soil nearby rotten wood in pine-tree forest with some aspen and birches.

results.notes:
General notes (14-Jun-15)
> These boletes were brought to the NJMA foray by new members who found them growing under oaks on their property in Landing, NJ. Unfortunately, as can be seen from the pix, the mushrooms were excessively handled before I took possession.
> The stipital ornamentation is particularly noteworthy, as it separates this taxon from other red-pored boletes with smooth stipes, and could be crucial for identification. In the mature fruitbody, the somewhat broken, irregular and scruffy vivid-red reticulation contrasts the pale yellow background color. The surface inside reticulation “cells” has a smattering of the same red scruffiness. The young basidiomata have much more red color in the stipe, and the reticulation is compressed into a highly textured and convoluted pattern, especially toward the apex.

DNA Sequencing Results (last updated 21-Jan-19):
> A clean and contiguous nrLSU sequence of the first 1444 bps has been obtained from this material. There are no ambiguous characters.
This sequence is 100% identical to the corresponding regions in the LSU sequences of obs 212358 (VT), obs 243052 (NJ), obs 244427 (NJ), and obs 251141 (PA), and obs 287453 (VA). However, in contrast to this result, none of these collections look like each other. Notably, the VA collection, completely devoid of any red tones (even in the pores), gives an impression of a totally unrelated taxon; it has certainly fooled me into thinking so.
A cladogram consisting of 34 relevant Neoboletus hits from this BLASTn search has been uploaded to this post.

> A clean, contiguous and complete (i.e., full-length) nrITS sequence of 689 bps was also procured. There are no ambiguous characters. This sequence is identical to that of obs 287453 (VA), sans two SNPs observed in the latter; the single haplotype of 206608 is present in 287453.
A BLASTn search of the ITS sequence gave eight (8) high-value hits, with similarities in the 99.1-100% range, associated with vouchers from northeastern North America that had not been confidently identified to species. A cladogram consisting of 38 relevant Neoboletus hits from this BLASTn has been uploaded to this post.
With regard to Boletus cf. subvelutipes voucher MES244 (ITS = #FJ480442, a 100% match), Prof. M. E. Smith was very gracious to supply a photograph of his collection via Dr. R. E. Halling (posted here). Most unfortunately, the greater part of the stipital surface below the apex has been eaten away by insects and/or slugs. What looks like “reticulation” on the lower half of the stipe is actually a pattern of bite marks left by the feasting critters. However, a close examination of the intact stipital apex strongly suggests that the stipe surface is not reticulate. Overall MES244 looks very much like a number of my red-pored collections from Washington Crossing State Park in NJ: https://mushroomobserver.org/species_list/show_species_list/1169.
A picture of Renee Lebeufs Boletales sp. voucher RL012 (ITS = #KY826167, also a 100% match), can be visualized at https://www.flickr.com/... and https://www.flickr.com/... (thanks for the links, Renee!).

> Lastly, a clean and contiguous 607 bps TEF-1- sequence was also procured. The sequenced region is between and including the EF1-983F and EF1-1567R primers. There are 3 ambiguous characters present, meaning that up to 8 haplotypes exist within this stretch of DNA.
A BLAST search focusing on the global Neoboletus is summarized in the attached GenBank-generated cladogram. The tree showcases relevant Neboletus hits from the USA, China and Europe. As can be seen from the diagram, the present collection is conspecific with several other sampled vouchers from eastern USA.
Careful comparison of this TEF-1- sequence with the corresponding overlapping regions in those of MO observations 212358, 243052, 244427, 251141, and 288090 (recall that the first 4 have matching LSU traces) shows that the sequences are essentially identical. The differences are present as a small and variable number of single nucleotide polymorphism (SNP) events at 7 specific positions shared between these organisms. Below is a summary of all numbered hetero-sites for these 6 collections (R = A & G; Y = C & T); the base count in this alignment starts from the 1st character of the EF1-983F primer:
.30…..108..422..443..489..590..599
206608YC.R………..YGC.C
243052TC.G.CG…C..C
244427YC.A.YG.Y.C
251141YC.A.TG….C.C
212358YC.R.YR.C.C
288090YY.R.YG.C.Y
As can be seen from the above table, only 243052 is represented by a single TEF-1- haplotype (no ambiguities), while 251141 with a single Y has two, 206608 & 24427 have eight, 212358 has sixteen, and 288090 (with 5 SNPs) has up to 32 haplotypes in the sequenced stretch of the gene. Since the observed ambiguity profiles for positions 422 and 443 are unique, not a single haplotype variant is shared by all collections. For example, the single haplotype of 243052 is present only in 206608, 212358 and 288090.

Discussion (last updated 23-Sep-19):
Based on the genetic data discussed above, this collection represents a rare phenotypic variant of several existing morphotypes of the most common and widespread hardwood-associated red-pored bolete species found in eastern North America. The presence of the pronounced and distinct stipital ornamentation (reticulation) alone perhaps a developmental anomaly or rather than a stable phenotypic trait separates it from the smooth-stiped presentation always seen in this taxon. The extreme morphological plasticity observed in this species can be readily appreciated from the images of the other 5 sequenced collections.
Despite the very broad species concept painted by these vouchers in terms of the colors of the cap pellicle, pores and stipe, falsely giving an impression of several species involved, the commonly encountered morphological presentation of this chameleon in fresh immature to mature fruitbodies can be summarized in the following brief description:
Orange-brown to reddish-brown to brownish-red (fox red) caps, orange to red pores (usually with a yellow rim around the margin), prominently yellow, smooth stipes covered with dark orange, red or brownish-red dots/pruina/squamules and frequently sporting burgundy-red stains and whitish to yellow to reddish strigosity at the base.
No wonder, this species has frequently been confused with and mistaken for the similar-looking and genetically related Boletus subvelutipes Peck by unsuspecting collectors! However, the current phenotypic and phylogenetic species concept of Pecks proverbial red-mouth bolete is that a conifer-associated (hemlock and spruce) entity exemplified by the following sequenced collections: obs 242312, obs 277482, obs 278342, obs 282008 and obs 285181.
As far as the limits of distribution are concerned, based on a number of other MO observations surmised to be the same taxon from their general appearance, this oak-loving red-pored bolete is very common in the northeastern quadrant of the USA from Maine south to at least northern Virginia and west to the Mississippi River. Collections from Michigan generally fitting the morphological profile have also been recorded (e.g., obs 293674, obs 311957, obs 321401, obs 322633, obs 335223). Thus, in all likelihood, this taxon was likely included by Smith & Thiers in their The Boletes of Michigan, and maybe even described by them as a sp. nov. For example, the descriptions B. erythropus f. michiganensis, B. rufocinnamomeus and B. subluridellus seem to generally fit the bill, especially the former one because its supported by a photo.

Cortinarius, sect. Calochroi. Cortinariaceae, Agaricales.
Whitish mushroom with light reddish-brown cutting and dots on a cap.
Cap: 3-5cm, convex or broad convex, margins curved in, smooth or fine velvety, whitish with some reddish-brown dots.
Gills: attached, close, narrow up to moderately broad, whitish with weak cream coloring, yellowish-white or cream when old.
Veil: partial cottony veil only at young mushroom.
Stalk: 5-10cm long, white with cottony cover when young up to brownish-white (reddish-brown after cutting), 0.8-1.6cm thick, slightly enlarged down, slightly fibrous.
Habitat: very rare kind in this location, single or small group on moss or soil in pine-tree forest with some birches in shady places of well-wooded forest.
Comments: observation #177334 from the other location possibly is the same kind, but older.
Edibility: no data.
Season: May-August

Psathyrella candolleana (Fr.) Maire, Corpinaceae, Agaricales. (Common Psathyrella, )
Cap: 2-6cm bell-shaped or convex up to broadly convex sometimes with gentle knob; whitish up to brownish-white or purplish-white; sometimes radial lined near margin. Young cap sometimes slightly fringed along margin or has rare tiny white flakes.
Gills: attached with notching, very close, moderately broad when old; color from whitish or pinkish-white, brownish-pink up to dark brownish-purple or purplish-black when old.
Spore print: dark purplish-brown.
Stalk: 5-12cm long, white up to purplish-white, fragile; 3-7mm thick, slightly enlarging down, hollow with edging; somewhat silky.
Edibility: good after boiling and becoming gray.
Habitat: crowded clusters minor small group nearby a base of deciduous trees along buildings.
Season: June – August.

results.notes:
Polyporus Ciliatus, Polyporaceae, Aphyllophorales. ( , .)

Cap: 4-9cm wide, gentle convex up to sunken, somewhat fine velvety with tiny needles along margin (as micro notched edge); light-brown with indistinct brownish-white spots, margin usually slightly curved in when young.
Flesh: 0.3-0.6cm thick, soft white or whitish with pleasant mushroom odor.
Tubes 1-3mm long, 6-9 per 1mm, bottom cap surface looks fine velvety, white (when young) then yellow-white.
Stalk: 3.5-7 cm long, 0.4-0.8cm thick, light brown and somewhat fine velvety or with darker dots.
Habitat: rather rare kind, single or small group at the old partially rotten deciduous stumps or trunks minor at pine tree rotten wood.
Edibility: good after boiling when young and not stiff.
Season: May-June.

results.notes: Truffles were found and given to me. Found in residence lawn by Birgitta Hietala when digging around base of spruce (black or Norway; I saw a twig but not the cones) trees. Were hypogeous. Smell very truffly, similar to Romano cheese; taste reported “mild, pleasant, a bit peppery aftertaste.” I did not taste them personally but the smell was fantastic. Size was about that of a pea (pretty small); a larger one that I did not see was reported to be 3-4 X the size of the others. Pretty smooth on the outer surface; lozenge-shaped to almost globose.

results.notes:
These three mushrooms had me a bit perplexed for awhile. Then I noticed a white-coated one in the same spot/habitat that was clearly in the process of being colonized by a Hypomyces. None of the three mushrooms seen here exhibit classic X. affine macro-traits. But I believe they are all examples of X. affine, at different stages of Hypomyces infection. The smallest one developed a thicker white mold covering after I brought it home.

results.notes:
Coprinus radians (Desm.) Fr., Coprinaceae, Agaricales. (Orange-mat Corpinus, ).

Orange-brown small bell-shaped crowded mushroom.

Cap: 1.5-3.5cm wide, egg-shaped when young then bell-shaped, light orange-brown up to dull orange-yellow; wrinkled lined toward orange top centre. Cap surface covered with whitish coarse dust and mealy granules when dry. Flesh is whitish and fragile when young.
Gills: attached, close up to crowded, narrow or moderately broad, pinkish-white or light lilac up to purplish-black and inky when died.
Stalk: 5-10cm long, 0.3-0.6cm thick and sometimes slightly enlarged toward base; white up to whitish, hollow; somewhat silky and indistinct fibrous.
Veil: universal and leaving evanescent (after rains) whitish mealy granules.
Edibility: too small and fragile mushroom and young period is very short.
Habitat: common kind in rainy time, crowded clusters nearby a deciduous wood base. This location is under trees between buildings.
Season: May – September.
Found on the lawn.

results.notes:
Habitat:
Growing under large old cedar tree. Growing among cider needles, moss and lichens.

Cap – Creamy tan color. Convex. largest 1 inch diameter. Edge slightly rolled in. I saw no evidence of a cortina or veil, even in the smallest.

Gills – off white – close with many short gills of varying lengths. Attachment – free.

Stalk – 1.25 inch long. 3/16 inch thick on largest. Darker than cap and gill color.

Spore Print – I looked at the spore print again under a brighter light. I think the spore print is tan, it is light – not yellow as previously reported.

Smell – not good, like rotting mushroom even when not rotting.

UPDATE
all I ever got was a very light spore deposit. It’s hard to say what color other than not white and not dark.

I’ve uploaded 4 photos of the spore. They are irregular, nodulose, small (~ 5-6 microns across), lumpy irregular surface. Some look like they are trying to have straight sides. Seems to agree with what I have found so far about Rhodocybe.

Microscopy:

When I re-wet one cap to cut up, the water turned a golden color. Similarly when I looked at gill sections everything looked golden. The slide prepared in H2O with a trace of wetting agent, became cloudy very quickly.

I prepared slides twice and could see cysts on the gill edges about 50 micron long and 1 micron wide. I could see short rounded basidioles.

I thought I could see the Sterigma on some basidia but they did not extend. The surface was covered with spores and all were filled with granular material.

I looked for clamped connections but found none.

SPORE MEASUREMENTS:
[20/1/1] L (-5.0) 5.1 6.1 (-6.6) m x W (-) 4.7 5.7 (-) m, (L = 5.6 m, W = 5.2 m), Q (-1.01) 1.04 1.15 (-1.16), Q = 1.09 Subglobose

Difficult to measure as spores are so irregular. I avoided measuring any spore image that was an end-on view. I did not measure spores that were badly misshapen.

Cortinarius (Pers.) Gray, Cortinariaceae, Agaricales.

Small mushroom with reddish-brown knobbed cap, reddish-brown stalk and gills

Cap: 2.5-5 cm wide, convex or gentle convex with a knob or blunt knob up to flatten or sunken with a gentle knob; reddish-brown with chocolate brown knob; surface smooth or glossy (when wet); often indistinct radial lined out of knob.
Gills: attached with notched edge (pinching end), light brown then reddish-brown up to grayish-brown when died, close and moderately broad with short and very short additional gills.
Stalk: 3-6 cm long, 0.4-0.8cm thick, hollow, whitish with reddish fibres, then purplish-brown up to grayish-brown when died; some fibrous with somewhat as white powder at a stalk surface (remnants of partial veil?).
Veil: partial veil is possible (remnants of whitish cover at a stalk?)
Edibility: no data for this mushroom.
Habitat: common kind in May; scattered small groups or crowded clusters in pine-tree forest
Season: May August (?).

results.notes:
Selected for the indicated MycoFlora sequencing project. NAMP collection MF54417.
Growing in a hemlock grove with a few white pines intermixed. Not much staining of the exposed context over the course of 20 min — light violaceous-gray (fuscous?).

DNA Sequencing Results (last updated on 6-Nov-17):
> A clean and contiguous 1380 bps nrLSU sequence was obtained for this material. There are no ambiguous characters. The first 60 bps from the start of the LSU region are trimmed away.
> A GenBank BLAST search of the full-length sequence hasn’t returned any meaningful hits.
> A GenBank BLAST search of a sequence fragment (the first 911 bps through the end of the LR5 region) produced two significant alignments with European conifer-associated red/orange-capped leccinum species:
1) 100% identity match (873/873 bps overlap, 95% coverage, no gaps) with L. vulpinum voucher KPM-NC-0017834 (accession #JN378516; collected in Scotland under P. sylvestris and identified by R. Watling)
2) 100% identity match (870/870 bps overlap, 95% coverage, no gaps) with L. piceinum strain Lp1 (accession #DQ534614; collected in Austria under P. abies and identified by M. Binder)
> Occurrence of vulpinum and piceinum in North America is likely according to Noordeloos and Kuo. Case closed.
